ğŸ“– Vol 3: Disciplining the Soul
Indeed, as for the life of seclusion [khalwa], its benefit is to repel distractions and to restrain the hearing and the sight, for they are the vestibule of the heart [qalb]. And the heart [qalb] is, in its ruling, like a basin into which foul, turbid, filthy waters pour from the rivers of the senses [hawas]. And the aim of spiritual discipline [riyada] is to empty the basin of those waters and of the silt produced from them, so that the basin's own source may gush forth and from it may emerge clean, pure water. And how can it be sound for him to bail water from the basin while the rivers are opened upon it, so that more is renewed at every moment than what is diminished? So it is necessary to restrain the senses [hawas] except from the measure of necessity, and that is not accomplished except through seclusion [khalwa] in a dark house. And if he has no dark place, then let him wrap his head in his sleeve or cover himself with a cloak or a waist-wrapper, for in a state like this he hears the call of the Truth [Haqq] and witnesses the majesty of the Divine Presence [al-hadra al-rububiyya]. Do you not see that the call to the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, reached him while he was upon such a description, so it was said to him: "O you who are wrapped [al-muzzammil]â€”O you who are covered [al-muddaththir]."

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Arrangement of Litanies
Indeed, the soul [nafs], as it is created with weariness and boredom, cannot persevere in a single mode of the means that aid in remembrance [dhikr] and contemplation [fikr]. Rather, if it is returned to one pattern, it displays boredom and a sense of burden. From the necessity of gentleness with it is that it should be refreshed by shifting from one mode to another and from one type to another, according to each time, so that its pleasure [ladhdha] may increase through the transition, its desire [raghba] may be magnified through the pleasure, and its constancy [mawÄáº“aba] may endure through the endurance of the desire. Therefore, the litanies [awrÄd] are divided into different portions, and remembrance [dhikr] and contemplation [fikr] should encompass all times or most of them. For the soul [nafs], by its nature, is inclined toward the pleasures [malÄdh] of the lower world [dunyÄ]. So, whoever wishes to enter Paradise without reckoning, let him immerse his times in obedience [á¹­ÄÊ¿a]. And whoever wishes for the scale of his good deeds [á¸¥asanÄt] to be weighted and the balances of his good works [khayrÄt] to be heavy, let him occupy most of his times in obedience [á¹­ÄÊ¿a]. This necessitates the immersion of the times of night and day in the duties of remembrances [adhkÄr] and contemplations [afkÄr], as God Almighty has said: "Indeed, the rising by night is most potent for subjugation and most upright for speech." This indicates that the standing of the night has a stronger effect in purifying the heart [qalb] and is more upright in rectifying speech and action, because it is a time empty of worldly distractions [shawÄghil dunyawiyya] and a clarity [á¹£afÄÊ¾] for the soul [nafs]. Thus, remembrance [dhikr] and contemplation [fikr] in it are more profound in attaining God-consciousness [taqwÄ] and vigilant awareness [murÄqaba].

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Arrangement of Litanies
Indeed, the path [tariq] to meeting Allah the Exalted is not completed except by dying while loving and knowing, and love [mahabbah] and intimacy [uns] are not attained except through the persistence of remembering the Beloved, and knowledge [ma'rifah] is not attained except through the persistence of reflecting upon His attributes and His actions, and that is not facilitated except by bidding farewell to the world [dunya] and immersing the times of night and day in remembrances [adhkar] and reflections [afkar]. And the soul [nafs], as it is created upon weariness, does not endure a single mode, but rather needs to move between litanies [awrad] so that its desire may persist. So whoever desires Paradise without reckoning, let him immerse his times in obedience. And for that reason, Allah the Exalted addressed His Messenger and His closest servants with His saying: "Indeed, for you by day is prolonged occupation. And remember the name of your Lord and devote yourself to Him with complete devotion." [73:7-8], to indicate that the persistence of remembrance [dhikr] and devotion [tabattul] by day and night is the way to tip the scale of good deeds and to reach the highest degrees with Allah, for in that is the cultivation of times with worship which purifies the soul [nafs] and draws it near to its Master.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Tawhid and Trust
Indeed, the third art is in engaging with the means [asbab] that repel harm [darar] which is exposed to fear [khawf]. Know that harm may be exposed to fear in the self [nafs] or wealth [mal], and it is not from the conditions of trust in God [tawakkul] to abandon the repelling means [asbab] outright. And abandoning the repelling means, even if it is severed, has a valid aspect if harm reaches him from a person. For if patience [sabr] is possible for him and repelling and seeking redress are possible for him, then the condition of trust in God [tawakkul] is endurance [ihtimal] and patience [sabr]. God, the Exalted, has said: "And leave their harm, and put your trust in God."

a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Sama and Wajd
Indeed, with Us are shackles [ankalan] and a Blaze [jahim], and food that chokes [ta'aman dha ghussatin], and a painful punishment ['adhaban aliman]. And Abu al-Darda' reported: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, said: "Hunger is cast upon the people of the Fire until it equals the punishment they are in. So they cry for relief with food, and they are given relief with food of *dari'* [dari'] which neither fattens nor avails against hunger. And they cry for relief with food, and they are given relief with food that chokes [ta'aman dha ghussatin]. And they are reminded just as they used to clear a choke [ghussatin] in the world [dunya] with a drink. So they cry for relief with a drink, and the scalding water [hamim] is raised to them with hooks of iron. So when it draws near to their faces, it scorches their faces. So when the drink enters their bellies, it cuts what is in their bellies. So they say, 'Call the keepers of Hell.' So they call the keepers of Hell, 'Call your Lord to lighten for us a day of the punishment.' So they say, 'Did not your messengers come to you with clear proofs?' They say, 'Yes.' They say, 'Then call. But the call of the disbelievers is only in error.' So they say, 'Call Malik.' So they call. So they say, 'O Malik, let your Lord decree for us.' So He answers them, 'Indeed, you will remain.'"

a.g: And food that chokes and a painful punishment -
On the Day the earth and the mountains will convulse and the mountains will become a heap of sand pouring down.
Indeed, We have sent to you a Messenger as a witness upon you just as We sent to Pharaoh a messenger.
But Pharaoh disobeyed the messenger, so We seized him with a ruinous seizure.
Then how can you fear, if you disbelieve, a Day that will make the children white- haired?
The heaven will break apart therefrom; ever is His promise fulfilled.
Indeed, this is a reminder, so whoever wills may take to his Lord a way.

Indeed, your Lord knows, [O Muhammad], that you stand [in prayer] almost two thirds of the night or half of it or a third of it, and [so do] a group of those with you. And Allah determines [the extent of] the night and the day. He has known that you [Muslims] will not be able to do it and has turned to you in forgiveness, so recite what is easy [for you] of the Qur'an. He has known that there will be among you those who are ill and others traveling throughout the land seeking [something] of the bounty of Allah and others fighting for the cause of Allah. So recite what is easy from it and establish prayer and give zakah and loan Allah a goodly loan. And whatever good you put forward for yourselves - you will find it with Allah. It is better and greater in reward. And seek forgiveness of Allah. Indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
